<h1> CarrotCake CMS Installation</a></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>1)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Download
a release ZIP archive from the CarrotCake CMS webpage and unzip the files into
its own directory.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>2)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Create
a site in IIS or provision a new dot net hosting account using your hosting
provider's control panel, depending on your hosting arrangements.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>3)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Copy
the files into your site's webroot.  If this is an update, you should only need
to upload the \bin\ and \Manage\ directory, other folders are (mostly) optional
if updating, and configuration files should be compared against your hosted
versions to confirm that you are running the configuration parameters.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>4)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Create
a new database on your server, or contact your hosting provider to perform the
operation.  If you are limited to a finite number of databases in your hosting
environment, you can share the same database and users across multiple sites. 
Be sure that each unique site its own unique <span style='font-size:9.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>CarrotSiteID</span>
value set in the web.config.  </p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.25in'>Users configured
as Administrators can log into any site that shares the same database, while
Editors must be mapped to individual sites for access purposes.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.25in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;
line-height:normal;text-autospace:none'>5)<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span>Update the database connection string entry in the web.config for <span
style='font-size:9.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>CarrotwareCMSConnectionString</span>
to match your database credentials, your hosting provider may provide the
string you need when they provision your database.</p>

margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.25in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:normal;
text-autospace:none'><span style='font-size:7.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>&nbsp;</span></p>

</span>Update the web.config section for <span style='font-size:9.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>&lt;</span><span style='font-size:9.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New";color:#A31515'>mailSettings</span><span
style='font-size:9.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>&gt; </span>to
reflect the network delivery settings appropriate for your ISP.  You can leave
the password field blank if you are not required to provide one or if your mail
server has whitelisted your web server.  This is important for password
retrieval purposes.  If this is not configured, if you forget your password,
you will have no way to get a new password sent to you.</p>

you can use the Visual Studio &quot;Create GUID&quot; functionality.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='text-indent:-.25in'>B.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Paste
the new GUID into the web.config of the admin project to replace the GUID entry
for <span style='font-size:9.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Courier New";
color:blue'>CarrotSiteID</span> .  If this is the first site with your
database, you can leave the GUID that is preloaded in the web.config file
as-is.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-indent:-.25in'>C.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Alternately,
comment out the web.config key for <span style='font-size:9.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>CarrotSiteID</span>, and open the
file SiteMapping.config and add entries to map a set of domain names to
different GUIDs.  This will allow a single webroot to provide different
content  based on different domain names.  This is similar to using different
host headers or bindings in IIS for a single webroot.  </p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst>Note: if <i>www.example.com</i> and <i>example.com</i>
need to provide the same site, you will have to add entries for both, but they
can point at the same GUID entry.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>8)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Upload
the modified configuration file(s) to your website's webroot.</p>

<span style='font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"'><br
clear=all style='page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>9)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Configure
the database</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-indent:-.25in'>A.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>If
your SQL credentials used in the web.config have dbo or higher rights, you can
simply go to the logon page of the CMS and the tables will be created/updated
for you.  Before updating an existing site you should logout of the CMS
administration.  If you have no pre-existing users in the database, you will be
prompted to create a new administrator.  You can create whatever
username/password you wish.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-indent:-.25in'>B.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>If
you wish to manually deploy updates, or do not have sufficient rights from the
credentials contained within the web.config, execute the provided scripts in
the order listed.  The scripts provided were generated from SQL 2008 Express,
they should also work on Standard 2008 or Standard 2008 R2 etc.  They may also
work on SQL 2005, but have not been tested.  Authentication is provided by SQL
Membership Provider.  </p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.75in;text-indent:-.25in'>1.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><strong><span
style='font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"'>CREATE 01 - whole database.sql </span></strong>--
will create the application tables.  Run this first.  It also includes the
membership provider schema and creates the security groups.  You can just run
this script and then go to the CMS logon page and create a new user, or you can
perform step 2.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:.75in;text-indent:-.25in'>2.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><strong><span
style='font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"'>CREATE 02 - default user.sql </span></strong>--
will create the default groups and an admin account with a default password. 
If you are building the application project yourself, point the web.config of
the CMSAdmin project at your new database.  You can fire up the ASP.Net
Configuration menu in Visual Studio and use that to create additional users. 
You will want to read the comments in the script and potentially edit according
to your needs.</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle>Additional scripts may appear for catch-up
if there are schema changes or plugin/module/widget purposes.  If you are using
a downloaded zip archive from the CarrotCake CMS project site, scripts will be
found in \_SQLScripts\</p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast>&nbsp;</p>
